narration:
Now, let's talk about work experience. This is an essential part of your application or CV, as it shows the employer what kind of skills and experiences you've gained in previous roles. When listing your work experience, make sure to include all types of jobs, whether full-time, part-time, paid, or unpaid.

For each job, provide the name of the employer along with a brief description of the company, just one or two sentences should be enough. Then, mention your job title and the key duties you performed in that role. It's also important to include who you reported to, their position within the company, the size of the team, and whether it was a multi-site operation.

When describing your responsibilities, try to group them into categories such as business process improvement, supplier negotiation, or customer focus. This will help highlight the transferable skills you've developed in previous roles. Remember to incorporate any key words mentioned in the job description or course requirements, as this shows that you have relevant experience and skills.

It's also worth noting that even if your work experience may not be directly related to the job or course, it can still provide valuable information for the employer. They want to get a sense of who you are, what you've achieved, and how you can contribute to their organization.

Now, let's move on to additional information. This is where you can include any relevant details about your IT skills, interpersonal skills such as team working or leadership, language proficiency, and achievements. However, be selective here – only include this information if it's truly relevant to the job or course. Don't just list a bunch of achievements because you think they'll impress the employer; make sure you can support each comment with evidence.
